S3.T1.caption: TABLE I: Summary of Notations
S3.T1.table:

Specifically, through an in-depth examination on the training process of gradient boosted decision tables, we manage to decompose the holistic secure design in the VFL setting into the design of a series of secure components run in a distributed manner among the participants, including secure node splitting, secure Sigmoid evaluation, secure discretization, and secure distributed decision table inference.
The delicate synergy of these secure components leads to the holistic protocol of Privet for privately training gradient boosted decision tables in the VFL setting.
Through the customized secure protocol, Privet outputs gradient boosted decision tables that are distributed among the involved participants, where each participant only holds a part of the model.
Subsequently, secure inference on the ensemble of learned decision tables can also be well supported in a distributed manner among the participants.
We implement and evaluate Privet’s protocols extensively over several real-world datasets as well as synthetic datasets.
The results demonstrate that Privet presents promising performance in computation and communication.
Meanwhile, the utility of the trained models in Privet is comparable to that in the plaintext centralized learning setting.

As illustrated in Fig. 2, a D𝐷D-dimensional decision table is equivalent to a full binary tree with D+1𝐷1D+1 levels, where each internal node from the 00-th level (for the root node) to the (D−1)𝐷1(D-1)-th level has a Boolean test; each edge is assigned the outcome of its source node’s test and each leaf node at the D𝐷D-th level is associated with an output value. Such equivalent tree is called oblivious tree, because all internal nodes at the same level share the same test, as opposed to generic decision trees that have different tests at the same level.
More specifically, the test at the d𝑑d-th level of an oblivious tree could be represented as Fd<tdsubscript𝐹𝑑subscript𝑡𝑑F_{d}<t_{d}, where d∈[0,D−1]𝑑0𝐷1d\in[0,D-1], the split feature Fd∈{X1,⋯,XJ}subscript𝐹𝑑subscript𝑋1⋯subscript𝑋𝐽F_{d}\in\{X_{1},\cdots,X_{J}\}, and tdsubscript𝑡𝑑t_{d} is the split threshold.
The special structure of oblivious tree results in its different training and inference methods from non-oblivious trees like CART [23].
In [15], Kohavi et al. first introduce a top-down construction of oblivious trees and use information gain as the evaluation metric to find the optimal test at each level. Different evaluation metrics are used in later studies, like mean squared error (MSE)[16] and Newton’s method[17].

Decision table outperforms generic decision tree in inference efficiency significantly. As illustrated in Fig. 2, each leaf node of an oblivious tree (the right sub-figure in Fig. 2) corresponds to a Boolean sequence and the comparisons required by D𝐷D tests could be parallelized. In contrast, inference in a regular decision tree is made by traversing the tree from the root node to a leaf node, which means the direction of the inference path after the current node depends on the test result of this node.

Note that while the evaluation of each decision node in generic decision tree inference can be parallelized, it is still necessary to traverse the tree from the root node sequentially so as to identify the correct leaf node that produces the inference result.
For example, as shown in the left sub-figure in Fig. 2, even if we parallelize the evaluation of each decision node, i.e., we obtain the sequence of test results [0,0,1,1,0]00110[0,0,1,1,0] by evaluating the 00-th split to the 444-th split simultaneously, we cannot directly identify which leaf node is finally chosen using [0,0,1,1,0]00110[0,0,1,1,0].
On the contrary, decision table inference is free of such sequential traversal [16, 17, 18].
As illustrated in the right sub-figure in Fig. 2, once the sequence comprised of Boolean test result at each level is obtained, the inference result can be immediately obtained because this Boolean sequence is also the identifier of a leaf node.

∙𝖬𝗎𝗅𝗍𝗂𝗉𝗅𝗂𝖼𝖺𝗍𝗂𝗈𝗇∙absent𝖬𝗎𝗅𝗍𝗂𝗉𝗅𝗂𝖼𝖺𝗍𝗂𝗈𝗇\bullet\mathsf{Multiplication}: To multiply a secret-shared value ⟦x⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑥\llbracket x\rrbracket with a constant c𝑐c (⟦z⟧=c×⟦x⟧\llbracket z\rrbracket=c\times{\llbracket x\rrbracket}), each participant multiplies its local share of x𝑥x by c𝑐c.
To multiply two secret-shared values ⟦x⟧,⟦y⟧\llbracket x\rrbracket,\llbracket y\rrbracket (denoted by ⟦z⟧=⟦x⟧×⟦y⟧\llbracket z\rrbracket=\llbracket x\rrbracket\times\llbracket y\rrbracket where z=x​y𝑧𝑥𝑦z=xy), the multiplication triple technique can be used [39]. In an offline phase, all parties obtain a secret-shared multiplication triple (⟦a⟧,⟦b⟧,⟦c⟧)(\llbracket a\rrbracket,\llbracket b\rrbracket,\llbracket c\rrbracket), where a,b𝑎𝑏a,b are uniformly random numbers in ℤ2Qsubscriptℤsuperscript2𝑄\mathbb{Z}_{2^{Q}} and c=a​b𝑐𝑎𝑏c=ab.
The secret-shared triples are data-independent and can be prepared and distributed offline by an independent third-party [40], so hereafter we assume the triples are available for use in online secure computation among the parties.
The secret-shared multiplication proceeds as follows.
Each party Pmsubscript𝑃𝑚P_{m} locally computes ⟨e⟩m=⟨x⟩m−⟨a⟩msubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑒𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑥𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑎𝑚\langle e\rangle_{m}=\langle x\rangle_{m}-\langle a\rangle_{m} and ⟨f⟩m=⟨y⟩m−⟨b⟩msubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑓𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑦𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑏𝑚\langle f\rangle_{m}=\langle y\rangle_{m}-\langle b\rangle_{m}. After that, the parties run 𝖱𝖾𝖼(⟦e⟧),𝖱𝖾𝖼(⟦f⟧)\mathsf{Rec}(\llbracket e\rrbracket),\mathsf{Rec}(\llbracket f\rrbracket). Next, Pmsubscript𝑃𝑚P_{m} computes ⟨z⟩m=j×e×f+f×⟨a⟩m+e×⟨b⟩m+⟨c⟩msubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑧𝑚𝑗𝑒𝑓𝑓subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑎𝑚𝑒subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑏𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑐𝑚\langle z\rangle_{m}=j\times e\times f+f\times\langle a\rangle_{m}+e\times\langle b\rangle_{m}+\langle c\rangle_{m}, where j=1𝑗1j=1 if m=1𝑚1m=1 and j=0𝑗0j=0 if m≠1𝑚1m\neq 1.
Table I summarizes the key notations in this paper.

We develop a secure decision table learning algorithm 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾\mathsf{SecTable} to support the secure training of a single (distributed) decision table in each round.
𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾\mathsf{SecTable} consists of several secure components, including (i) secure node splitting 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍\mathsf{SecSplit}, (ii) secure Sigmoid evaluation 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽\mathsf{SecSigmoid}, and (iii) secure discretization 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼\mathsf{SecDisc}.
The secure node splitting component 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍\mathsf{SecSplit} (Section 5.2.1) is to securely split the nodes at a certain level and partition the index sets associated with these nodes without revealing the partitioned index sets.
The secure Sigmoid evaluation component 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽\mathsf{SecSigmoid} (Section 5.2.2) inputs a secret-shared value and calculates the Sigmoid function in the secret sharing domain.
The secure discretization component 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼\mathsf{SecDisc} (Section 5.2.3) is to securely rearrange the secret-shared gradients according to the local permutations owned by each participant and then group them into buckets.
Through the synergy of these components, 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾\mathsf{SecTable} allows the participants to securely train a distributed decision table in each round, for which we will give the details in Section 5.2.4.

After securely training a distributed decision table in a certain round, secure inference needs to be conducted, of which the result will be added to previous inference results (line 9) for use in 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾\mathsf{SecTable} in the next round.
To this end, we develop a secure distributed decision table inference protocol 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer} (Section 5.3), which inputs each participant’s local data and partial model to produce secret-shared inference results without leaking their data and partial model.
It is worth noting that 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer} can also be used to support secure inference for new data after the completion of the whole training process.

After learning the d𝑑d-th test Fd<tdsubscript𝐹𝑑subscript𝑡𝑑F_{d}<t_{d}, the participant who owns Fd<tdsubscript𝐹𝑑subscript𝑡𝑑F_{d}<t_{d} cooperates with other participants to securely split all the nodes at the d𝑑d-th level with 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍\mathsf{SecSplit} to create a new level (line 32). A decision table in Privet is learned level by level in this way.
At the D𝐷D-th level, Privet securely calculates output values for the 2Dsuperscript2𝐷2^{D} leaf nodes following Eq. 3 (i.e., lines 34-37 in Algorithm 6), where the division is securely calculated with 𝖲𝖣𝗂𝗏𝖲𝖣𝗂𝗏\mathsf{SDiv} in Section 5.2.2.
Finally, 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾\mathsf{SecTable} outputs a distributed decision table consisting of D𝐷D tests and 2Dsuperscript2𝐷2^{D} secret-shared output values.
Specifically, all participants know the split feature Fdsubscript𝐹𝑑F_{d} at the d𝑑d-th level where d∈[0,D−1]𝑑0𝐷1d\in[0,D-1], but each split threshold tdsubscript𝑡𝑑t_{d} is only available to the participant who owns the feature Fdsubscript𝐹𝑑F_{d}.

In Privet, each decision table in the ensemble learned in the secure training phase is held by the participants in a distributed manner, where each participant holds a part of it.
Recall that in our secure VFL framework (Algorithm 2), once a distributed decision table 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} is securely learned in a certain round, we need to perform secure inference over the training data using 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}.
The the produced inference results at this round will be securely aggreagted with previous inference results for use in securely training a new distributed decision table in the next round.
To prevent the partial model and local data on each participant from leaking during the secure inference process, we propose a secure distributed decision table inference protocol 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer}, which relies on secure multiplication of indicator vectors to conduct privacy-preserving inference, as shown in Algorithm 7.
𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer} allows the participants to cooperatively perform secure inference on their local data utilizing the distributed ensemble and produce secret-shared inference results while keeping the local data and partial model not unavailable to other participants throughout the inference process. We introduce the design of 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer} as follows.

We take the inference of sample (“H​e​i​g​h​t=175𝐻𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡175Height=175”, “W​e​i​g​h​t=55𝑊𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡55Weight=55”, “S​a​l​a​r​y=11000𝑆𝑎𝑙𝑎𝑟𝑦11000Salary=11000”) as an example. The three features are vertically partitioned and held by P1,P2,P3subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3P_{1},P_{2},P_{3}, respectively. For the first test “H​e​i​g​h​t<170𝐻𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡170Height<170”, P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} locally compares “H​e​i​g​h​t=175𝐻𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡175Height=175” with the threshold 170 and generate leaf indicator vector 𝐮0=(0,0,0,0,1,1,1,1)subscript𝐮000001111\mathbf{u}_{0}=(0,0,0,0,1,1,1,1) to guide the inference path because 175>170175170175>170. Similarly, we can get 𝐮1=(1,1,0,0,1,1,0,0)subscript𝐮111001100\mathbf{u}_{1}=(1,1,0,0,1,1,0,0) and 𝐮2=(0,1,0,1,0,1,0,1)subscript𝐮201010101\mathbf{u}_{2}=(0,1,0,1,0,1,0,1). Each leaf indicator vector is then secret-shared among all participants.
Recall that in the basic decision table inference introduced in Section 3, the comparisons required by different Boolean tests are parallelized to accelerate inference due to the oblivious tree structure. Although the learned decision tables in the ensemble in Privet are distributed and secret-shared, their oblivious structure remains unchanged, and thus operations at different levels can still be parallelized.
After the sharing of leaf indicator vectors, the inference result of this sample can be obliviously calculated by element-wise multiplication as follows: ⟦𝐮0⟧×⟦𝐮1⟧×⟦𝐮2⟧×⟦𝐰⟧\llbracket\mathbf{u}_{0}\rrbracket\times\llbracket\mathbf{u}_{1}\rrbracket\times\llbracket\mathbf{u}_{2}\rrbracket\times\llbracket\mathbf{w}\rrbracket. In this way, each participant will not know which path in the distributed decision table is used during the secure inference process.

We first compare the accuracy of two approaches: our Privet and plaintext centralized learning of gradient boosted decision tables.
For the Cal Housing dataset, we set T=50𝑇50T=50 to build 505050 decision tables in the ensemble model and 555 to limit the dimension of each decision table. The number of buckets B𝐵B is set as 323232. For the Credit dataset, we set T=10𝑇10T=10, D=4𝐷4D=4 and B=32𝐵32B=32. For the Breast Cancer dataset, we set T=10𝑇10T=10, D=3𝐷3D=3 and B=32𝐵32B=32.
Following other works on gradient boosting [8], more decision tables are trained for regression tasks to guarantee accuracy.
We use the identical parameters in Privet and plaintext.
For the regression tasks, we use the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) as the evaluation metric.
For the evaluation of classification tasks, we report the results using two commonly used metrics: Accuracy (ACC) and Area Under the ROC Curve (AUC).
The accuracy of Privet and plaintext on both regression and classification tasks are reported in Table III.

S7.T4.caption: TABLE IV: Privet’s Computation and Communication Performance
S7.T4.table:
Dataset Online Secure Training
Time (seconds) Comm. (GB)
Cal Housing 6333 41.141.141.1
Credit 1724 11.811.811.8
Breast Cancer 486 0.540.540.54
references:
We now report the computation and communication performance of Privet in secure training over the three public datasets, and present the results in Table IV.
We also note that to evaluate the efficiency of Privet over larger datasets, we use three synthetic datasets, of which the results are reported in Section 7.4.

From the results in the first two records of Table IV, we can observe that the training time and communication cost of Privet on Cal Housing is significantly more than that on Credit, which is because we train 50 decision tables on Cal Housing but only 10 decision tables on Credit.
However, Privet consumes an average of 127 seconds to train a 5-dimensional decision table on Cal Housing and 172 seconds to train a 4-dimensional decision table on Credit.
There are mainly two reasons for this observation: (1) the number of features and the number of samples of Cal Housing are less than that of Credit. (2) dealing with classification tasks additionally needs secure Sigmoid evaluation compared with regression tasks, which will result in more computation and communication overhead.

From the results in the last two records of Table IV, we can observe that although the scale of Credit is nearly 50 times larger than that of Breast Cancer, the training time on Credit under similar parameters is only roughly 4 times that on Breast Cancer.
This is because Privet securely discretizes training data into buckets, and all the time-consuming computations are conducted on the buckets.
In this way, the training cost is highly correlated with the number of buckets, instead of the number of training samples.
In fact, this also indicates the strong scalability of Privet, which will be demonstrated in detail in the next section.
